description:
Die ALKOR ist ein regionales Forschungsschiff fr alle Disziplinen, das der deutschen und europischen Meeresforschung dient. Das Fahrt- und Einsatzgebiet umfasst hauptschlich die Ostsee mit Kattegatt und Skagerrak sowie die Nordsee und die Kste vor Norwegen. Das 55 Meter lange Schiff verfgt ber vier Labore, in denen unter anderem Luft-, Wasser- und Sedimentproben untersucht werden knnen. Primre Forschungsdisziplinen der ALKOR sind die Ozeanographie, Biologie, Fischereibiologie, Geophysik sowie Geologie. Das Forschungsschiff bietet Platz fr 12 Wissenschaftler:innen.

Gebaut wurde die nach einem Stern im Bild des Groen Bren benannte ALKOR als Nachfolgerin eines gleichnamigen Forschungskutters, der 1990 nach 24 Jahren im Dienst der Wissenschaft den Anforderungen an Technik und Umweltfreundlichkeit nicht mehr entsprach. Die heutige ALKOR unternimmt Expeditionen mit deutschen und europischen Forschergruppen. Sie ist darber hinaus bei Lehr- und Praktikumsfahrten fr Studenten im Einsatz. Von der ALKOR aus knnen ebenfalls das Tauchboot JAGO sowie ROV PHOCA und AUV ABYSS eingesetzt werden. Sie ist ein Schwesterschiff der auf Helgoland beheimateten HEINCKE.

Zurzeit wird die ALKOR durch die Briese Schiffahrts GmbH bereedert. Sie hat die Fahrterlaubnis Groe Fahrt gem Funkgebiet A2. Die Standzeit in See betrgt 21 Tage. Eine Grundberholung und Modernisierung des Schiffes wurde Ende 2010 abgeschlossen.

description: The sail yacht Eugen Seibold is a research vessel designed for contamination-free sampling of seawater, plankton, and air. Starting from 2018, exchange processes between atmosphere and ocean are studied. S/Y Seibold operates in the Atlantic Ocean and marginal seas, and the eastern Pacific Ocean. The 72-ft vessel has a gross weight of 48 tons, and is autonomous for up to 3 weeks, carrying 4000 L of diesel, 1000 L of potable water, and a desalination plant. The design of the S/Y Seibold, with a glass fiber reinforced composite hull, and up to 12 hours of battery mode autonomy facilitates contamination-free sampling of seawater and air. Call Sign: CRA7241. The Eugen Seibold is operated by the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry, Mainz, Germany.

description: MOSES devices currently in storage in Potsdam

Moses Hydrologische Extreme, Sternfahrt April 2019. The MOSES Sternfahrt was carried out by the three ships Mya II (Cuxhaven-Helgoland), Prandtl (Cuxhaven-Helgoland) and Littorina (Bsum - Helgoland) and back respectively. The aim of the cruise was to coordinate the three ships to record large-scale distribution patterns of basic water parameters, greenhouse gases (air and water), radiation in the Elbe estuary. The trip was divided into two days. On the first day the cut was driven from the mainland to the island, on the second day the cut from the island to the mainland. The routes are given in the document MOSES Sternfahrt 1. The measurements are supplemented by the FerryBoxes on the two passenger ships MS Helgoland and MS Funny Girl. The route of the Mya II was the same as the route of the MS Helgoland, the route of the Prandtl was the same as the route of the MS FunyGirl, the Littorina leads the Eiderschnittstrecke. On the first day there was a rendezvous with the MS Helgoland (Mya II) where the MS Helgoland stopped and the Mya II took a profile with water samples. The exact position of the rendevouz was the 7 station in the plan. The geneune coordinates are stored in the DSHIP system of the Mya. The Prandtl met the MS FunnyGirl and the MS FunnyGirl did not stop while the Prandtl drove a profile with water samples. Littorina: enter action. 
On 16.04 on the route to Helgoland between 7 and 10 depth profiles (Mya II CTD578, Prandl , Littorina ) were taken from all ships additionally at fixed stations (see route planning). The water samples were taken with 3 replicas each (connected samples from the same creator). The three replicas are analysed independently at the three institutes (HZG, GEOMAR, AWI).

longName: ISOLAB Facility - Stable Isotope Laboratory Potsdam
description: The ISOLAB FACILITY of the AWI in Potsdam develops and utilizes stable H, O, C, N isotope methods to decipher Quaternary environmental change on in polar regions of both hemispheres. The Laboratory for Stable Isotopes at AWI Potsdam does research in the Polar Regions of both hemispheres on natural materials such as water, ice, organic matter form soils and sediments and biogenic opal (i.e. diatoms). We use analyses on stable oxygen, hydrogen, carbon and nitrogen isotopes to reconstruct the climate and environmental dynamics in high latitudes (both Arctic and Antarctic research). The research focus region is Siberia. The scientific orientation of research projects imcludes scientific applications of stable isotope methods in permafrost research, palaeoclimate studies, by also in the fields of limnology, hydrology, ecology and glaciology.

longName: HZG Model of Circulation in North and Baltic sea
description:
" A nested grid circulation model for the German Bight 
The circulation modelling-platforms in COSYNA is based on the nested-grid General Estuarine Transport Model (GETM, Burchard and Bolding, 2002). GETM is a primitive equation prognostic three-dimensional hydrodynamic model. The use of generalized vertical coordinates makes it  suitable for shallow coastal regions under the influence of tidal currents. In this model the  equations for the three  velocity components, sea-surface height, temperature, salinity, as well as the  equations for turbulent kinetic energy and the eddy dissipation rate due to  viscosity are solved. A particular feature of GETM is its ability to  adequately represent the dynamics in deep inlets and channels as well as on  the tidal fats, the latter falling dry during part of the tidal period.

The nested-grid model consists of three  model configurations: a coarse-resolution North Sea-Baltic Sea (~ 5 km) outer model, a fine-resolution (~ 1 km) inner model covering  the German Bight and a very fine-resolution (~ 200 m) model for the  Wadden Sea region resolving the barrier islands and the tidal flats. The  bathymetric data for the different model configurations are prepared using  the ETOPO-1 topography, together with observations made available from the BSH.

Terrain following equidistant coordinates  (s-coordinates) are used for the vertical dimension.  The water column is discretised into 21 nonintersecting layers. The model system is forced by: (1) atmospheric fluxes estimated by the bulk formulation using 1-hourly forecasts from the German Weather Service (DWD), (2) hourly river run-off data provided by the BSH operational model, and (3) time-varying lateral boundary conditions of sea surface elevations and salinity. The sea surface elevations of the open boundary of the North Sea-Baltic Sea model are generated using tidal constituents obtained from the TOPEX/POSEIDON harmonic tide analysis. Temperature and salinity at the open boundary of the outer model are interpolated at each time step using the monthly mean climatological data.

References:
Burchard H, and K. Bolding, 2002: GETM, a general estuarine transport model. Scientic Documentation, No EUR 20253 EN, European Commission, 157 pp

description:
A primary magnetic field is generated by an alternating current flowing through a transmitter coil, which causes eddy currents in the conductive underground through induction. The resulting secondary magnetic fields, together with the primary magnetic field, are registered by a receiver coil.  
The CMD Explorer is a multi receiver coil, EM conductivity instrument with receiver coils at 1.48m, 2.82m and 4.49m from the transmitter, in vertical dipole mode, this equates to effective depth penetrations of 2.3m, 4.2m and 6.7m respectively. In Phase (magnetic susceptibility) and Quadrature Phase (conductivity) readings can be made from all 3 dipoles simultaneously. The CMD Explorer offers a simple user interface and serial/Bluetooth communications for integrating Geospatial positions from an external GPS system. The coil oriantation can be changed from vertical dipoles (Horizontal Co-Planer) to Horizontal dipoles (Vertical Co-planner) by rotating the probe tube through 90.
companyName: Helmholtz-Zentrum fr Umweltforschung GmbH - UFZ
name: Uta Kdel

description: Two Basler BT-67 aircraft have been specially modified for flying under extreme polar conditions. Their landing gear, which combine skis and conventional tyres, allow them to land on and take off from concrete, gravel or snow. Thanks to de-icing systems, heating mats for the batteries and engines, and advanced navigation systems, the craft can even fly blind on instruments alone, safely land despite severe weather, and operate at temperatures down to -54 degrees Celsius.

description: The Aquadopp current meter is designed for any body of water, whether ocean, estuary, lake or river. Current meters measure the water current velocity in a single volume. is comprised of 2 MHz acoustic transducers that transmit short bursts of sound into the water. The sound propagates along narrow acoustic beams and is scattered by small particles or zooplankton suspended in the water. The echo that reaches the transducers is analyzed for change in frequency (Doppler shift) and water velocity is calculated along each of the acoustic beams. By combining the velocities with the exact beam geometry, either 2D (2 beams) or 3D (3 beams) velocity is calculated and recorded on the internal recorder or reported online. In addition to velocity measurements, the Aquadopp contains compass and tilt sensor making it possible to measure the orientation of the instrument.
companyName: Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research

description: The Moving Vessel Profiler (MVP) is used for underway profiling of ocean temperature, salinity, depth, chlorophyll and rhodamine. The system consists of a winch with 440 m of 4-conductor tow cable, a winch frame with an outrigger and an attached sheave, and a tow fish. The towed fish carries an AML Micro CTD package (SN 9068) composed of a conductivity, temperature and pressure Xchange sensors as well as a Turner Cyclops-7F fluorometer to measure concentrations of rhodamine dye or chlorophyll.
companyName: GEOMAR Helmholtz-Zentrum fr Ozeanforschung Kiel
name: Claas Faber

description: The Teledyne Oceanscience Underway-CTD (uCTD) is a compact ship-based system for the measurement of conductivity and temperature profiles while the vessel is underway. It consists of a probe, winch, rewinder, davit and a power supply. During uCTD sampling, the probe internally records pressure, temperature and conductivity data. After the probe is retrieved, the data are transferred to a laptop using the wireless transfer technology Bluetooth

description: RAMSES radiometers are spectral imaging radiometers to measure radiance, irradiance, or scalar irradiance in the UV, VIS and UV/VIS ranges. Thanks to their ultra small size and weight as well as very low power consumption, they are especially suitable for hand-held and autonomous applications. RAMSES radiometers combine precision hyperspectral light measurements with a maximum of flexibility. The modular system increases cost-effectiveness, while the many accessories and special solutions enable a wide range of applications such as installation on ships, handheld usage or autonomous measurements in remote places, like the Arctic or Antarctica.

description: The WindCube200 is an active remote sensor based on Light Detection And Ranging technique. The heterodyne LIDAR principle relies on the measurement of the Doppler shift of laser radiations backscattered by the particles in the air (dust, water droplets, aerosols). A modulated laser pulse is sent into the atmosphere. The return signal is mixed with a reference laser beam (i.e., local oscillator) of the modulated frequency, then the Doppler frequency shift from the power spectra of the heterodyne signal will be determined and though  the wind speed along the line of the beam. Laser pulse is emitted in different directions  (four times 90 rotated each under 15 against zenith). The time for the light pulse to travel out to the target and back to the LIDAR is thereby used to determine the range to the target (e.g. the height). With the four measurements in different directions and the height information it possible to calculate a three dimensinal wind field with a time resolution of 10 min and up to 5 km and an accuracy of 50 m.

description: The Aethalometer model AE33 collects aerosol particles continuously by drawing the aerosol-laden air stream through a spot on the filter tape. It analyzes the aerosol by measuring the transmission of light through one portion of the filter tape containing the sample, versus the transmission through an unloaded portion of the filter tape acting as a reference area. This analysis is done at seven optical wavelengths spanning the range from the near-infrared to the near-ultraviolet. The Aethalometer calculates the instantaneous concentration of optically-absorbing aerosols from the rate of change of the attenuation of light transmitted through the particle-laden filter.

longName: Aerosol-sampling for chemical analysis (ions) at SPUSO
description: Aerosol is continuously sampled using a ventilated electropolished stainless steel inlet stack. Starting in March 1983 through 2011 we used a high volume (HV) sampling device. From the in-line air stream, aerosol was continuously sampled at 120 m3 h-1 on two pre-cleaned Whatman 541 cellulose filters (240 mm diameter) in series. The samples refer to a temporal integration of 7 to 14 days which corresponds to sample volumes of around 2x104 m3 to 4x104 m3 STP, respectively. From 2012 ongoing, we exclusively relied on the low volume (LV) sampling device. Thereby aerosol was sampled using a 2-stage filter system, consisting of a teflon and a nylon filter connected in series. Roughly 60 m3 (STP) of ambient air was probed over a typical collection period of 24 hours. Samples were analyzed for MSA, Cl-, NO3-, SO42-, Na+, NH4+, K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+ by ion chromatography.

description: MeBo70 is a portable drill rig which is remotely operated from the vessel. This drill rig is capable of sampling soft sediments and hard rocks down to 80 m at the sea floor with a total core length of more than 70 m. It can be operated in water depths up to 2000 m.  MeBo70 was designed by MARUM in close cooperation with several companies. MARUM was responsible for system concept, project management, sensor integration, control hard- and software development and overall system integration. A steel armoured umbilical manufactured by the Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke (NSW) is used to lower the MeBo70 to the sea bed. Copper wires and fibre optics in the umbilical core are used for energy supply and for communication. The MeBo70 uses the Remote Systems Engine from Schilling Robotics as telemetry system. This company also developed the loading arm and the rotating magazines that are used for storage of the required drill tools on the rig

description: Measures pHT (total hydrogen scale) in the marine pH range of 7-9. Uses a highly accurate colorimetric reagent method. System does not suffer from the drift that plagues most electrode based pH probes. Designed to provide researchers with valuable in-situ time series data at depths up to 600 meters. 234-day deployment capability (hourly measurements, 25C). Extra battery package allows the SAMI-pH to run for more than a year. Can support up to 3 external instruments (e.g., PAR, dissolved oxygen, chlorophyll fluorometer, CTD). Supports Seabird underwater inductive modems or external loggers via RS-232
companyName: Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research

description: Prosilica GT2750 is a 6.1 Megapixel camera with a GigE Vision Gigabit Ethernet interface. This camera incorporates a high quality Sony ICX694 EXview HAD CCD sensor that provides high sensitivity, near IR response, low noise, anti-blooming, and excellent image quality. It is a rugged camera designed to operate in extreme environments and fluctuating lighting conditions. This camera offers Precise iris lens control allowing users to fix the aperture size to optimize depth of field, exposure and gain without the need for additional control elements.
companyName: Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research
name: Mario Hoppmann

description: The WP-2 (WorkParty-2) net is used for quantitative, depth-integrated capture as well as qualitative capture of zooplankton organisms for experimental work. The net is generally used in vertical hauls, although specific water layers can also be sampled selectively. For this purpose, a closing mechanism is used that can be triggered at a certain water depth with a weight falling from the wire. The net frame usually has a diameter of 57 cm and is equipped with a flowmeter, which is attached to the net frame. The WP-2 net can be equipped with different mesh sizes; 100, 200 or 400 m are often used.
companyName: Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research
name: polarstern dship

longName: Ammod A1 Volumetric Air Sampler Prototype2
description: The A1 volumetric air sampler is an airborne pollen trap, especially suitable for autonomous eDNA-metabarcoding analyses. The trap can sample pollen in 24 different tubes with flexible intervals, allowing it to operate independently in the field for a certain amount of time.
companyName: MARUM - Zentrum fr Marine Umweltwissenschaften

longName: Iridium GPS Communication System for Drifting Traps
description: Iridium Beacon for determination of position of the drifting sediment traps during deployment. One beacon is located on the drifting trap and sending the position of the trap. Another beacon is located on the ship to receive the transmitted positions.

The system consists of a highly modular and flexible optical system (light sources, lens set-up), onboard CTD measurement, battery power and an telemetry unit with deck system to online observe particle detection and adjustment of settings.
